Pd-Ni bimetallic nanoparticles supported on active carbon as an efficient catalyst for hydrodeoxygenation of aldehydes Jia-wei Zhang a Kang-kang Sun a Dan-dan Li a Tao Deng b Guo-ping Lu a Chun Cai a ⁎ a Chemical Engineering College, Nanjing University of Science & Technology, 200 Xiaolingwei, Nanjing 210094, PR China Chemical Engineering College Nanjing University of Science & Technology 200 Xiaolingwei Nanjing 210094 PR China b Institute of Tropical Medicine, Guangzhou University of Chinese Medicine, Guangzhou 510405, PR China Institute of Tropical Medicine Guangzhou University of Chinese Medicine Guangzhou 510405 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract A recyclable Pd-Ni bimetallic nanoparticles supported on active carbon is fabricated and applied in the HDO of aldehydes. “Synergistic effect” between the two metal components and interaction between BMNPs and the carrier (active carbon) all contribute to outstanding catalytic performance of Pd1Ni4/AC catalyst. A highly efficient bimetallic nanoparticles (BMNPs) catalyst was reported, Pd1Ni4/AC, consisting of Pd1Ni4 BMNPs supported on active carbon, shown excellent catalytic performance and stablity in hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of vanillin. HDO of vanillin and various aldehydes with high efficiency and selectivity could be achieved at low H2 pressure (2 bar) under mild conditions in the presence of the BMNPs catalyst, no obvious decrease on catalytic performance was observed after eight cycles. The superior catalytic performance of the Pd1Ni4/AC catalyst was mainly attributable to the synergetic electronic effect between Pd and Ni, which showcased the great potential of BMNPs in the catalysis field. Keywords Biofuels Bimetallic nanoparticles Hydrodeoxygenation Hetergeneous catalysis Vanillin 1 Introduction With decreasing fossil-based energy reserves and increased environmental concerns related to CO2 emissions, research focused on production of biofuel and chemical feedstocks from renewable and sustainable biomass sources has attracted extensively attention. [1–5] Biofuel, produced via flash pyrolysis of biomass, is regarded as a prospective alternative energy source for the limited crude oil [4–8]. However, high oxygen and unsaturated degree make the unrefined biofuel have low energy density (20 MJ kg−1), low thermal and chemical stability (pH 2.5), [9,10], which limits its direct combustion in modern diesel engines. [6,11–13], Hence, an upgrading process was required to improve its quality before application as a conventional liquid transportation fuel. [14,15], During the last decades, several approaches like hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) [16], zeolite cracking [17] and aqueous-phase reforming [18] have been established for biofuel upgrading, and HDO appears to be the best choice as it obviously decrease the oxygen content of the crude biofuel [19]. High diversity in biofuel makes evaluation of upgrading process difficult, [20] vanillin (4-hydroxy-3-metho-xybenzaldehy-de), a common component of pyrolysis oil derived from the lignin fraction [16,21], was typically chosen as a model substrate to study the HDO process of biofuel. Conventional HDO process of biofuel catalyzed by sulfided NiMo and CoMo catalysts often proceed under severe conditions, which leads to the formation of substantial amounts of gases and char, results in low energy efficiency [22]. Therefore, development of catalysts to realize upgrade of biofuel under mild conditions is still urgent [1,12]. Since the end of the 20th century, a large number of catalytic systems have been confirmed efficiently for the HDO of vanillin. [23] Wang et al have reported the fabrication of mesoporous N-doped carbon supported Pd catalysts (Pd@CN0.132) for bio-oil refining, high nitrogen (12 wt%) content in the catalyst carrier offer a good dispersion in water and high activity in stabilizing Pd nanoparticles. [24] Xiao et al have established a mesoporous sulfonated melamine–formaldehyde resin supported palladium nanoparticles catalyst (Pd/MSMF) for biofuel upgrade, superior catalytic performance was related to the good wettability of the vanillin reactant to the Pd/MSMF catalyst [6]. El-Shall et al report a bifunctional catalyst Pd/SO3H-MIL-101(Cr) for the biomass refining, outstanding catalytic performance of Pd/SO3H-MIL-101(Cr) is attributed to the unique characteristics of the SO3H-MIL-101(Cr) support, which leads to not only very stable and uniform dispersion of the Pd nanoparticles but also possible electronic activation of the reactants and good dispersion of the catalyst in water. [25] Impacts of supports’ properties on the catalytic performance have been fully discussed in those cases, but reports focus on the active sites for the HDO reaction is rare. BMNPs, which was typically prepared by mixing two metal components within a single catalyst pioneering contributed by Sinfelt [26], stimulated intensive research interests worldwide due to its unique catalytic performance compared with traditional monometallic analogues [27]. The last decades witness the development of BMNPs catalysts, which have been proved to be efficient for a range of reactions [26–29]. Doping noble metals with earth abundant metal elements seems to be an ideal solution to improve the catalytic performance (activity, selectivity and durability) while minimizing the usage of noble metals [30]. Quite recently, Mondal et al designed a Cu-Pd nanoalloy catalyst immobilized on a porous organic polymer (Cu3Pd@BBA-1) for the HDO of vanillin, superior catalytic performance was ascribed to the intrinsic synergistic effects caused by the modulation of the electronic structure involved in the Cu-Pd bimetallic interfaces. [1] Varma et al reported AgPd@g-C3N4 as an active catalyst for the HDO of vanillin using formic acid to upgrade the biofuels under visible light irradiation, outstanding catalytic activity was due to the synergistic effect of Ag and Pd with the graphitic carbon nitride support and their mutual interaction. [31] In light of these outstanding works and our previous experience on the bimetallic nanoparticles (BMNPs), [32–36] we expect to explore the catalytic activity of Pd based BMNPs for the HDO of vanillin. Toward this end, a Pd-Ni BMNPs catalyst supported on active carbon (Pd-Ni/AC) was established as an advanced catalyst for the HDO of vanillin, the reaction proceeded under a mild condition. Catalyst and the solvent could be recycled for at least 8 times without obvious loss in catalytic performance. Excellent catalytic performance of the Pd-Ni/AC catalyst may attributable to the intrinsic synergistic effects of BMNPs and the catalytic cooperation between the carrier and BMNPs. 2 Experimental section 2.1 General considerations All chemical reagents are obtained from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. Gas Chromatography-Mass Spectrometer (GC–MS) was performed on an ISQ Trace 1300 in the electron ionization (EI) mode. Gas Chromatography (GC) analyses are performed on an Agilent 7890 A instrument. TEM images were taken using a PHILIPS Tecnai 12 microscope operating at 120kv. Energy Dispersive X-ray Spectroscopic analysis (EDS) was performed with a JEM-2010(HR) transmission electron microscope at an acceleration voltage of 200 kV. High Resolution Transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) was performed on Philips-FEI Tecnai G2 F20 operating at 300kv. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) were performed on a ESCALAB 250Xi spectrometer, using a Al Kα X-ray source (1350 eV of photons) and calibrated by setting the C 1 s peak to 284.80 eV. Inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) was analyzed on Optima 7300 DV. 2.2 Preparation process of the catalyst The supported nanoparticle catalysts were prepared by an impregnation-reduction method, composition of the nanoparticles were controlled by adjusting the ratio and category of the metal precursors. In a typical procedure, Pd1Ni4 BMNPs supported on active carbon (AC) were prepared as following: 10 mg PdCl2 and 53.4 mg NiCl2·6H2O was dissolved in 20 mL DI water, L-lysine (154 mg) was added into the mixture after dissolution of the metal precursors. After ultrasonic radiation for 30 min, 1 g active carbon was added into the mixture. The mixture was vigorously stirred for 30 min under argon atmosphere. After that, NaBH4 aqueous solution (45 mg dissolved in 5 mL DI water) was added drop wisely at 4 °C, the mixture was further stirred for 30 min. And then 15 mL acetone was added into the mixture, the catalyst was further aged for 24 h without stirring. Finally, the solid was separated, washed (water and ethanol) and dried at room temperature under vacuum. Other catalysts used in this manuscript were prepared in the same way except that metal precursors and catalyst support are different. 2.3 Typical process for HDO of vanillin 0.5 mmol of vanillin and corresponding catalyst were sealed in an autoclave containing 2 mL of deionized water, which was purged with H2 for 3 times. The pressure of H2 was adjusted to the desired value and the autoclave was kept at 90 °C for 2 h, the mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate and the catalyst was taken out from the system by centrifugation before being analyzed by gas chromatography. Dodecane was added as an internal standard. 3 Results and discussion To evaluate the catalytic performance of the as synthesized BMNPs catalyst, HDO of vanillin was selected as a model for biofuel upgrade. HDO of vanillin may produce the hydrogenolysis product (2-methoxy-4-methylphenol) and the hydrogenation product (vanillin alcohol), the desired hydrogenolysis product 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol (2) is regarded as a potential future biofuel. [31] Water was used as the solvent considering its environmentally friendly nature, low cost and easy handling. Initially, the HDO reaction was carried out in the presence of the Pd1Ni4/AC catalyst, full conversion of vanillin to 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol could be achieved over 0.8 wt% catalyst within 2 h (Table 1 , entry 1). Active carbon was chosen as the carrier due to its low cost, high surface area and strong absorbability for organic molecules. Besides, carbon can be made directly out of biomass, which endows it the most “sustainable” host materials for metal nanoparticles. [37] Active carbon used in this work was acidized with nitric acid to gain better hydrophility and better absorptivity for metallic ions. The as synthesized Pd1Ni4/AC catalyst dispersed well in water (Fig. S5, ESI), which may improve the exposure of the catalyst to the substrates, thereby boosting the catalytic efficiency. Subsequently, the Pd1Ni4/AC catalyst was compared with other oxide-supported Pd1Ni4 BMNPs (entries 2∼5), these results indicate that properties of the carrier have a huge impact on the catalytic performance. Better catalytic performance of Pd1Ni4/AC might be ascribed to the strong absorbability of active carbon for organic molecules and its good dispersion in water, which lead to highly efficient contact between the reactant molecules and the active sites. FT-IR analysis was carried out to verify the absorbability of the catalyst for vanillin. As shown in Fig. S6 (SI), Pd1Ni4/AC and Pd1Ni4/SiO2 show excellent absorbability for vanillin, intensities of the FT-IR peaks corresponding to the vanillin decreased dramatically, and some of them disappeared entirely, indicating that vanillin was adsorbed into the micropores of the catalyst upon interaction with the catalyst. Doping carbon with nitrogen atoms could increase its hydrophilic property and retention ability for NPs, so g-C3N4 and nitrogen doped carbon derived from cellulose was attempted as the carrier for Pd1Ni4 BMNPs. But almost no product was detected (entries 6, 7), which could be ascribed to the strong binding of nitrogen to metal atoms. Further optimization process indicated that a quantitative yield of desired product was obtained with 0.4 wt% Pd loading under 2 bar H2 (entry 8). Further decreasing on the H2 pressure or the reaction temperature caused incomplete conversion of the substrate and intermediate (entries 910). As a comparison, mono-metallic catalyst Pd/AC and Ni/AC were also tested in this reaction. Pd/AC shown poor selectivity for the desired product 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol (below 50%) (entry 11), no reaction transpired when Ni NPs was used as the catalyst (entry 12), which indicates that Pd is the active site for the HDO reaction. No significant enhancement in catalytic performance was detected while using physical mixture of Pd/AC and Ni/AC as the catalyst (entry 13), indicating that no bimetallic synergistic effects exist in this case. Evaluation on effect of BMNPs composition on the catalytic performance was also conducted (entries 14–20). It was found that increasing the Ni content in the BMNPs could obviously enhance the catalytic efficiency for the HDO reaction (entry 14 vs 15). Replacing Ni in the BMNPs catalyst with Cu or Co caused significant loss in catalytic activity and selectivity (entry 1 vs 16, 17). Moreover, we also tested BMNPs catalyst based on other noble metals (entries 18–20). No reaction transpired in the presence of the Ru1Ni4/AC catalyst (entry 18), poor selectivity for the hydrogenolysis product was achieved when Pt1Ni4/AC catalyst was used as the catalyst (entry 19). All the vanillin was hydrogenized into vanillin alcohol in the presence of Ir1Ni4/AC catalyst (entry 20), indicating its strong catalytic activity for the hydrogenation reaction. Furthermore, to explore the practical applications of the as synthesized bimetallic nanoparticles, the reaction was carried out with a vanillin/Pd (substrate/catalyst) molar ratio of S/C = 350. A vanillin conversion of 84% with a 2- methoxy-4-methylphenol selectivity of 65% was achieved within 1 h at 90 °C, compared with the literate data obtained using Pd@CN0.132 as the catalyst under almost the same condition (except that the hydrogen pressure is 1 Mpa) [24], we could conclude that the as-synthesized BMNPs catalyst shown better catalytic performance under a mild reaction condition. Dependencies of the reactant and product concentr-ations on reaction time over the Pd1Ni4/AC catalyst were shown in Fig.1 , the experiment performed at 90 °C under 2 bar H2 in water. As it can be seen, vanillin is hydrogenated into vanillin alcohol at the early stage of the reaction, then, hydrogenolysis of vanillin alcohol proceeded rapidly. Almost all of the vanillin alcohol had been converted to 2-methoxy-4-methylphenol via hydrogenolysis within 2 h. These results indicated that the HDO process proceeded via vanillin alcohol intermediates. Microstructure of the BMNPs has been investigated by performing transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (Fig. 2 ). The TEM images revealed that the BMNPs are well dispersed on the carrier and size of the nanoparticles mainly distribute among 2 and 5 nm, the ultrafine nanoparticles provides more contact opportunity between the active sites and the reactants, which was the prerequisite for high catalytic efficiency. High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) analysis was used to verify the formation of BMNPs, as shown in the inset of Fig. 2a, the nanoparticles have clear crystalline fringe patterns and the lattice distance is measured to be 0.21 nm, which could be assigned to the d-spacing of the (111) plane of the PdNi alloy. TEM-EDS mapping of the Pd1Ni4/AC catalyst was also carried out (Fig. 3 ), which indicates a uniform distribution of Ni and Pd elements in the catalyst. Details of the surface composition and chemical states of the Pd1Ni4/AC catalyst were analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Typical XPS survey scans of the as-synthesized Pd1Ni4/AC catalyst were shown in Fig. 4 a, revealing that the Pd1Ni4/AC catalyst contains C, O, Ni and Pd. The XPS spectra points out that the ratio of the surface concentration between Ni and Pd is 7.2, while the ICP-MS results indicates that ratio between Ni and Pd in the catalyst is 3.45, difference in the atomic ratio indicates enrichment of Ni on the surface of BMNPs. As displayed in Fig. 4 (b), the peaks centered at the binding energies of 284.8 and 288.4 eV are corresponding to sp [2] carbon and C = O species [38,39]. High oxygen content on the catalyst surface may enhance catalyst dispersion in water and improve the exposure of the catalyst to vanillin. The XPS Pd 3d5/2 peak can be deconvoluted into two peaks, 334.8 and 336.1 eV, corresponding to Pd° and Pd2+, respectively (Fig. 3c). [40] It’s worth noting that over 90% Pd on the surface is in the metallic form, while 40% Pd on the Pd/AC surface was in the Pd2+ form, which indicates that formation of alloy might prevent Pd from oxidation. In Fig. 3d, the Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2 peaks appear at 856.2 and 874.0 eV, and the satellite peaks at 861.5 and 880.0 eV are characteristics of Ni2+, presence of Ni2+ may be caused by the oxidation of surface Ni when exposed to oxygen and moisture. [41,42] Besides, peak located at 852.5 eV could be assigned to Ni°, which was reported to be a characteristic peak of Ni-Pd alloy [43]. What’s more, compared with corresponding monometallic nanoparticles (Fig. S1, SI), the location of Pd peaks in the Pd-Ni BMNPs shifted toward lower BE, while location of Ni peaks shifted toward the higher BE, these results indicate a strong electronic interaction between Pd and Ni through formation of alloy. Moreover, there is great electro heterogeneity on the BMNPs surface due to the electronegativity discrepancy between Pd and Ni. [44] Electro heterogeneity could accelerate the heterolysis of H2 on the BMNPs surface [34,36,45] as well as the interaction between the active sites and the adsorbed reactant molecules [46], therefore significantly speed up the hydrogenolysis process. To further demonstrate functional group tolerance and potential applications of this protocol, HDO of aldehydes with different functional groups was also investigated. As shown in Table 2 , benzaldehydes with different electron-donating groups underwent smooth transformation under the optimized condition (entries 1∼4). But in the case of 4-(trifluoromethyl)benzaldehyde (entry 5), no desired product was detected, the substrate was totally hydrogenated into 4-(trifluoromethyl)benzyl alcohol (entry 5). It’s worth noting that 5-Hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF), an important platform chemical obtained from abundant cellulose, can also be efficiently transformed into 2, 5-dimethylfuran (DMF) (entry 6), which was regarded as a promising biofuel with high energy density and octane number. [47–49] Moreover, polycyclic aromatic aldehydes was also tolerated under the optimized condition (entry 7), showing an excellent applicability of the established HDO protocol. Heterogeneous nature of Pd1Ni4/AC catalyst was verified by hot filtration experiments (Fig. 5 ), the catalyst was filtered when the reaction was carried out for 30 min and 60 min, and it was confirmed that no reaction proceeded after remove of the catalyst. Besides, no obvious Pd or Ni leaching was observed by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis of the filtrate, which clearly confirmed that active specie in the catalytic system is the heterogeneous metallic nanoparticles. Finally, reusability of the Pd1Ni4/AC catalyst was also investigated, reactants and the products were extracted from the reaction mixture upon completion of the reaction with ethyl acetate (3*2 mL), solvent and catalyst were directly reused in the next cycle. As shown in Fig. 6 , the catalyst delivered excellent catalytic activity and selectivity for at least eight cycles. Unaltered morphology of recycled Pd1Ni4/AC catalyst illustrates their structural stability (Fig. S4, ESI), average size of the recycled BMNPs was measured to be 4.1 nm, and we think the increased size and oxidation of the surface metal atoms may be the origin of the drop of catalytic performance. 4 Conclusion In summary, a heterogeneous bimetallic catalyst has been developed for the HDO of vanillin, a common component in lignin-derived bio-oil. The developed Pd1Ni4/AC catalyst exhibits high catalytic activity and selectivity in the HDO of vanillin and a serious of aldehydes, excellent catalytic performance was still remained after recycled for eight times. The high catalytic performance of Pd1Ni4/AC is mainly attributed to the following reasons: (i) The acid treatment carbon guarantees a uniform dispersion of the BMNPs and good dispersion of the catalyst in water. (ii) Active carbon has strong absorbability for organic molecules, which may improve the exposure of the active site to the substrates. (iii) The ultrafine size of BMNPs ensures an excellent hydrogenation ability of the catalyst as well as a well contact between the active sites and the reactants. (iv) Electronic interaction between Pd and Ni in BMNPs could accelerate the heterolysis of H2, which may greatly speed up the hydrogenolysis process. The outstanding catalytic performance of BMNPs catalyst in our work validates the natural advantages of BMNPs, and we believe that the superior BMNPs catalyst may have promising potential for the biofuel upgrade process. Conflicts of interest The authors declare no conflict of interest. Acknowledgements We gratefully acknowledge Chinese Postdoctoral Science Foundation (2015M571761, 2016T90465) for financial support. This work was a project funded by the Priority Academic Program development of Jiangsu Higher Education Institution. We also thank Wan-ying Tang at Analysis and Test Center Nanjing University & Technology for the help in obtaining the ICP-MS data Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary material related to this article can be found, in the online version, at doi:https://doi.org/10.1016/j.apcata.2018.10.038. coredata.dc:description: A highly efficient bimetallic nanoparticles (BMNPs) catalyst was reported, Pd1Ni4/AC, consisting of Pd1Ni4 BMNPs supported on active carbon, shown excellent catalytic performance and stablity in hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) of vanillin. HDO of vanillin and various aldehydes with high efficiency and selectivity could be achieved at low H2 pressure (2 bar) under mild conditions in the presence of the BMNPs catalyst, no obvious decrease on catalytic performance was observed after eight cycles. The superior catalytic performance of the Pd1Ni4/AC catalyst was mainly attributable to the synergetic electronic effect between Pd and Ni, which showcased the great potential of BMNPs in the catalysis field.
coredata.dc:title: Pd-Ni bimetallic nanoparticles supported on active carbon as an efficient catalyst for hydrodeoxygenation of aldehydes
